journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Viscous dissipation effects on the limiting value of Nusselt numbers for a shear-driven flow through an asymmetrically heated annulus

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kalyani Government Engineering College, India

author-notes.corresp: Pranab Kumar Mondal, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kalyani Government Engineering College, Kalyani 741235, India. Email: pranab2k3@yahoo.com

abstract.p: In this study, an analytical investigation for analyzing the effects of viscous dissipation on the limiting Nusselt number for a hydro-dynamically fully developed laminar shear-driven flow through an asymmetrically heated annulus of two infinitely long concentric cylinders has been made, where the inner cylindrical rod is moving in an axial direction at a constant speed. On the basis of some common assumptions, an analytical framework has been devised to explore the effects of viscous dissipation on the heat transfer characteristics for the flow of Newtonian fluid, and, consequently, closed-form expressions for the limiting Nusselt numbers are evaluated. In the analysis, focus has been given on the viscous dissipative effect due to the shear produced by the movable inner cylindrical rod apart from the viscous dissipation due to internal fluid friction for the flow of a Newtonian fluid. The interactive effects of the Brinkman number and degree of asymmetry on the limiting Nusselt number are analytically investigated. It is observed from this study that the limiting Nusselt number becomes independent of Brinkman number when both the walls of the annulus are kept at an equal temperature. Moreover, the temperature profile in the conduction limit obtained with the consideration of viscous dissipation effect provides a boundary condition required for solving energy equation including the axial conduction in the fluid.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the last few years, fluid flow in small devices and the resulting heat transfer have drawn attention as remarkable advancement has been made in the field of microelectronics and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS). The dissimilarity in thermal behavior in small devices is mainly due to the rise in temperature, which is primarily attributable to the viscous dissipation effect. In small devices, inefficient heat dissipation leads to local overheating problems. The understanding of the fluid flow phenomena through micro-scale devices has been critically reviewed, exploring the physics of the flow emphasizing the use of MEMS in different areas for flow control.1 In the domain of the macroflows, there are so many practical applications where heat transfer normally occurs in the fluid flow system involving moving boundaries. Particularly, in many material processing applications such as extrusion, hot rolling, drawing, and continuous casting, materials continuously move in a channel. In such industrial applications, it is of great importance to study the heat transfer from the moving boundary to the surrounding fluid and vice versa. However, the moving boundary deforms the fluid velocity profile, and shears the fluid layer near the boundary, resulting in local changes in velocity gradient. Thus, the viscous dissipation effect may not be neglected in heat transfer analysis associated with moving boundaries. The thermal energy generated due to the viscous dissipation is significant near the wall, which alters the heat transfer rates following the changes in the temperature profile. In order to obtain the actual heat transfer rate in the application of moving boundaries, it is important to take into account the effects of viscous dissipations using accurate velocity distribution. The first theoretical work,2 concerning the heat generation due to viscous dissipation has analyzed the effects of viscous heating for the flow of a single phase Newtonian fluid through a circular tube. The temperature distribution in the thermal entrance region has been examined considering zero temperature of the wall and an insulated wall. The temperatures were found to be the highest, not surprisingly, within a small area near the wall region. The available literatures in the area of convective heat transfer have, however, considered the effects of viscous dissipation to be important in two cases: flow of very viscous fluids and flow in capillary tubes. A numerical analysis has been performed to study the influence of viscous dissipation for the flow of Newtonian fluid in a parallel plate channel.3 Following the numerical analysis, an investigation has been made to explore the onset of the instability for longitudinal vortices in the entrance region of the channel with the thermal boundary condition of an isothermally heated lower plate, and cooled upper plate. The effects of viscous dissipation on laminar forced convection for the flow of Phan-Thien-Tanner fluid through a pipe and channel have been studied.4 The study has revealed that the viscous dissipation enhances the fluid elasticity. Performing an analytical study, using a functional analysis method, an investigation has been made to explore the effects of viscous dissipation on the heat transfer of thermally developing laminar Hartman flow through a parallel plate channel with the aid of a magnetic field.5 In a study of thermal development of forced convection in a parallel plate channel filled with porous medium, the effects of viscous dissipation have been investigated with the thermal boundary condition of uniform wall temperature including axial conduction effects.6

In a pioneering work by White and Muller,7 the effects of viscous heating on the stability of Taylor–Couette flow have been investigated experimentally. The study has considered Newtonian and viscoelastic fluid for experimental exploration of the critical Reynolds number for the onset of the transition to a new state. However, the study has revealed that for a high viscous fluid, viscous heating expedite the transition, and promote it to occur at a critical Reynolds number much lower than the inertial transitional Reynolds number. In another work, analysis of laminar forced convection in a pipe for Newtonian fluid of constant properties has been performed,8,9 by taking the effect of viscous dissipation into account. In Part-1, both hydro-dynamically and thermally fully developed convections have been studied, while Part-2 of the study has considered the hydro-dynamically developed but thermally developing case. In both cases, two different types of thermal boundary conditions have been considered, namely, constant heat flux (CHF) and constant wall temperature (CWT). The variations of dimensionless radial temperature and Nusselt number have been obtained for different values of Brinkman number under both wall heating and cooling. The influence of viscous dissipation on heat transfer has been found to be strong for higher values of Brinkman number (Br > 1), while it has been negligible for lower values of Brinkman number. In the thermally developing case, comparing the temperature distribution with that of the same obtained by neglecting the viscous dissipation, it has been observed that the temperature distribution increases in the axial direction, which is attributable to the effect of the viscous dissipation. In that study, influence of the Brinkman number (for the case CWT) and the modified Brinkman number (for the case CHF) on the development of the Nusselt number has also been investigated. The analytical work done by Aydin and Avci,10 has dealt with the convective heat transfer problem for the plane Poiseuille flow with an emphasis on the viscous dissipation effect. The energy equation has been solved for thermally developed and developing cases separately with the boundary conditions of CWT and CHF, respectively. In both cases, the flow has been considered to be hydro-dynamically developed. It has been found from the study that with the increasing intensity of viscous dissipation (i.e. increase in Brinkman number), the heat transfer decreases up to a critical value, and that is attributed to the internal heat generation due to the viscous dissipation effect. In a study, as an extended work of Aydin and Avci,10 the viscous dissipation effects on fixed parallel plates with CHF boundary condition have been investigated.11 Various analytical expressions of Nusselt number as a function of the Brinkman number have been obtained by several researchers as evident from the reported investigation. These include the effects of viscous dissipation in laminar heat transfer for a Poiseuille flow in stationary parallel plates for Newtonian as well as non-Newtonian fluids. The steady-state laminar heat transfer to a plane Poiseuille–Couette flow of a Newtonian fluid with simultaneous pressure gradient and axial movement of one of the plates has been investigated by several investigators.12–15 In another work, the laminar heat transfer due to a Couette flow with pressure gradient using the power-law model for a non-Newtonian fluid has been reported.16 In all these cases, the energy equation containing viscous dissipation term has been solved numerically to obtain the effects of viscous dissipation on the heat transfer for the two different thermal boundary conditions of either temperatures being specified at both the plates, or there being a specified temperature at the stationary plate with moving plate insulated. A numerical study has been performed,17 to investigate the influence of viscous dissipation on fully developed laminar heat transfer to a non-Newtonian fluid flowing between two parallel plates with one of the plates having an axial movement. However, the study has concentrated on the boundary conditions of constant wall heat flux at one wall with the other being insulated, where the focus has been on the viscous dissipation effects. In a recent study, the effects of viscous dissipation on heat transfer of a power-law fluid within fixed parallel plates with the CHF boundary condition have been probed.18 The study reveals that the heat transfer depends on the power-law index of the fluid considered, and strongly influenced by the viscous dissipation effects.

All the research mentioned above have dealt with the effect of viscous dissipation on convective heat transfer in a Poiseuille flow for a hydro-dynamically fully developed flow between two parallel plates, considering both the cases––thermally fully-developed and developing. No work has been reported so far, on the laminar forced convection in the limiting condition, giving the quantitative relation between the different performance index parameters of heat transfer including the viscous dissipation effect for a shear-driven flow through an annulus of two concentric cylinders kept at constant unequal temperatures.

The objective of this article is to explore analytically the combined effects of the Brinkman number and the degree of asymmetry on the temperature profile and, hence, to determine the limiting Nusselt numbers in the condition mentioned above. For this, a detailed analytical study is carried out to investigate the effect of viscous dissipation on the heat transfer for a shear-driven flow for varying degrees of asymmetry in the wall heating.

The article is split-up into four sections: in ‘Problem formulation’ section, the details of the problem are discussed and the analysis of the problem taken-up for the study following the introduction part is described. Next ‘Results and discussions’ are explained, and finally major ‘Conclusions’ are summarized.

sec.title: Physical considerations
Analysis of the problem
sec.p: Specifics to the problem considered in the study are the incompressible and axis-symmetric continuity, momentum and energy equations. The relevant equations are as follows:
Continuity equation (1)∂vz∂z=0
Momentum equation (2)1r∂∂r(r∂vz∂r)=0
Energy equation
The governing equation for the thermal energy conservation in the conduction limit, neglecting the convective terms is given by (3)k1r∂∂r(r∂T∂r)+μ (∂vz∂r)2=0

However, in order to express (equations (2) and 3) in a non-dimensional framework, it is essential to define the non-dimensional parameters suitably. From the physical considerations discussed above, following non-dimensional parameters are chosen V=vzU, R=(r-R1)(R2-R1), R*=R1R2 and θ=(T-T¯)(Tf-T¯)

It is important to mention here that the temperature Tf is the uniform fluid temperature and T¯ the average wall temperature. To take the effect of unequal wall temperature into account, a parameter to characterize the asymmetry in the wall heating is defined. The parameter is identified as the degree of asymmetry, and it is symbolized by β=(T2-Tf)/(T1-Tf) .
The non-dimensional fully developed velocity profile is expressed as (4)V=1ln(R1R2)ln(rR2)

However, with the aid of the above non-dimensionless parameters, and using the (equations (3) and 4), following dimensionless temperature profile in the conduction limit is obtained, subjected to the boundary conditions of unequal constant temperatures, θ=-(1-β)/(1+β) at R=0 ; and θ=(1-β)/(1+β) at R=1 . (5)θc=B2[ln{R*+R(1-R*)}]2 -(2lnR*(1-β)(1+β)+BlnR*2)[ln{R*+R(1-R*)}] +(1-β)(1+β)
In order to have deeper insights regarding the heat transfer characteristic, the bulk mean fluid temperature in the conduction limit Tmc is defined as (6)Tmc=∫R1 R2ρvzTCdA∫R1 R2ρvzdA

The heat transfer at the inner wall of the annulus is expressed as (7)q1c=h1c(T1-Tmc)=-k ∂T∂r|r=R1 where h1c , the convective heat transfer coefficient, is related to other parameters as (8)Nu1c=h1c(R2-R1)k=-[1/(θ1-θmc)] (∂θc∂R)|R=0

In a similar fashion, the limiting Nusselt number at the outer wall of the annulus is expressed as (9)Nu2c=h2c(R2-R1)k=[1/(θ2-θmc)] (∂θc∂R)|R=1.0 where θmc is the dimensionless bulk mean temperature in the conduction limit, and θ1 and θ2 are the non-dimensionless temperature at the inner and outer walls of the annulus, respectively. It is pertinent to obtain the expression of θmc and the closed-form expression of the limiting Nusselt number at both the walls. However, equation (7) may be normalized to yield (10)θmc=(1-β)(1+β)+4I1[Br4R*2lnR*+(3a12-a2)I2] where I1 to I2 and a1 and a2 , each of which is a function of R* , are given below I1=[R*2(1-2lnR*)-1]
I2=[R*2(lnR*)32-R*2(lnR*)22+R*2lnR*4-lnR*4]
a1=-Br2(lnR*)3
a2=Br2(lnR*)2-2(lnR*)2(1-β)(1+β) Equation (8), in conjunction with equation (10), establishes an explicit expression for the limiting Nusselt number at the inner wall of the cylinder, giving quantitative relation among the different physical parameters governing the thermo-fluidic transport. It is given as (11)Nu1c=-(1-R*)lnR*[2{(1-β)/(1+β)}+(Br/2)]2(1-β)(1+β)+4I1[Br4R*2lnR*+(3a12-a2)I2]
Proceeding similarly, the expression of limiting Nusselt number at the outer wall of the annulus is established as follows: (12)Nu2c=(1-R*)lnR*[2{(1-β)/(1+β)}-(Br/2)]4I1[Br4R*2lnR*+(3a12-a2)I2]

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The Brinkman number is an important parameter governing the heat transfer and fluid flow through an annulus of two concentric cylinders. The effects of viscous dissipation in a fluid flow and heat transfer are best described by the use of the Brinkman number. This study aims at finding out the influence of the viscous dissipation effects on the temperature profile, and, consequently, the Nusselt numbers in the conduction limit. Here, the effect of Brinkman number for a hydro-dynamically fully developed flow through an asymmetrically heated annulus is analyzed. In the process, three different degrees of asymmetry parameter, β=0.5 , -0.5 , and 1 have been considered to exhibit the effect of the same on the heat transfer characteristics.

Figure 2(a) to (c) depicts the variation of dimensionless temperature profile in the limiting condition within the annulus for different values of Brinkman numbers, obtained at three different cases of asymmetrical wall heating, β=0.5 , -0.5 , and 1, respectively. All the figures shown above correspond to a particular value of aspect ratio of annulus, R*=0.5 . In this case, three different values of Brinkman number Br=0.5,-0.5 , and 0 have been under consideration. Viscous dissipation always generates a distribution of heat source, stimulating the internal energy in the fluid. As a result, the temperature profile gets distorted, which is envisaged from the above figures. A close look on the above figures also reveals that in the cases with Br≠0 , the profile of the dimensionless temperature gets altered in comparison with in the case of Br=0 , though the imposed boundary condition on the walls remains invariant. The reason behind such a behavior of the dimensionless temperature profile obtained at different Br is attributable to the effect of viscous dissipation arisen owing to the shear-stress within the fluid layer induced by the movement of the inner cylindrical rod. In the thermal entrance region, a linear trend of developing dimensionless temperature θc is observed for all the case of wall heating (except β=1 ) for Br=0 , which is a pure conduction profile. It is, however, worthwhile to observe from the above figures that the non-existence of viscous dissipation makes the temperature distribution to be independent, irrespective of the asymmetry of the wall heating. Positive values of Br are compatible with the wall heating case, which resembles the situation of heat transfer to the fluid across the wall. Therefore, for the cases with positive values of Br , the fluid temperature increases, where as the reverse is true for the negative values of Br , as reflected on the above figures. A close look at the above figures reveals the significant influence of the degree of asymmetry on the variation of θc with R. However, in case of symmetric heating, i.e. at β=1 , θc shows a non-linear variation with Br (except Br=0 ) in a symmetrical way satisfying the boundary condition imposed on the walls. Interestingly one can observe from Figure 2(a) and (b) that the limiting value of the dimensionless temperature at the inner and outer walls of the annulus are equal but opposite in sign, which can also be established from equation (5). Figure 2.
Dimensionless temperature profile for: (a) β=0.5 , (b) β=-0.5 , and (c) β=1.0 , for different values of Br .

Figure 3(a) and (b) shows the variation of the dimensionless bulk mean temperature in the conduction limit, θmc versus R* , for different values of Br obtained from equation (10), corresponding to the cases with β=0.5 and β=-0.5 , respectively. It is important to observe that the variation of the dimensionless bulk mean temperature with R* is strongly influenced by the degree of asymmetry in wall heating, β. This is due to the inequality of the average wall temperature of the annulus and the limiting value of the bulk mean temperature even at Br=0 . However, one may notice from Figure 3(a) and (b) that for any non-zero value of Br , the variation of θmc with R* is symmetrical about the profile of the same obtained at Br=0 , which can also be established from equation (10). Figure 3.
Dimensionless bulk-mean temperature profile for: (a) β=0.5 and (b) β=-0.5 , for different values of Br .

To demonstrate the effects of viscous dissipation on the heat transfer characteristics, the variation of limiting Nusselt number in the annulus for different degrees of asymmetry in the wall heating is shown. Figure 4(a) to (b) depicts the variation of limiting Nusselt number on the inner wall of the annulus with Br , for two different degrees of asymmetry in the wall heating β=0.5 and β=-0.5 , respectively. Equations (11) and (12) clearly indicate that both the limiting Nusselt numbers are dependent on two variables, e.g. the degree of asymmetry in wall heating, β and Br , and will vary with Br for β≠1 and with β for Br≠0 . Figure 4.
The influence of Br on: (a) Nu1c for β=0.5 , (b) Nu1c for β=-0.5 , (c) Nu2c for β=0.5 , (d) Nu2c for β=-0.5 , and (e) Nuc for β=1 .

However, one may notice a continuous decreasing trend of Nu1c with increase in R* from the above figures for both the cases of wall heating. It is observed from the above figures that the limiting Nusselt number at the inner wall of the annulus, Nu1c depends on Br for the cases with β≠1.0 , which shows similarity in behavior when the effects of viscous dissipation are taken into account in presence of externally applied magnetic field.19 It is essential to remember that the positive value of Br corresponds to the wall heating case, which resembles the situation of heat transfer to the fluid across the wall resulting in an increase in Nusselt number in comparison to the case where Br is neglected. However, the reverse is true for the negative value of Br , which is reflected on the variation of Nusselt number as one may observe from Figure 4(a) and (b).

The influence of Br on the variation of limiting Nusselt number at the outer wall of the annulus, Nu2c with R* is illustrated in Figure 4(c) and (d) for two different degrees of asymmetry β=0.5 and −0.5, respectively. It is interesting to observe that for both the cases of asymmetrical heating, Nu2c increases with R* for all Br considered in the study. Contrary to the variation of Nu1c versus Br , a decreasing trend of Nu2c with increasing Br is observed for any particular R* , as apparent from the above figures. However, this opposing trend of Nu2c is attributable to the decreasing temperature gradient with increasing Br at the outer wall of the annulus. An important observation for the cases with β≠1 can be made from Figure 4(a) to (d) that for any given Br , the limiting value of Nusselt number on both the walls of the annulus does not match as R*→1 . This, however, may be attributed to the movement of the inner cylinder, which increases the heat transfer at the inner wall of the annulus.

Actually, the axial movement of the inner cylinder provides additional shear stress in the fluid, which increases the viscous heating resulting in an enhancement in the heat transfer at the inner wall of the annulus. Moreover, an observation of dependence of the limiting Nusselt number on Br , R* , and β is found to be important when β≠1 . Conversely, the variation of the limiting Nusselt number on both the walls of the annulus is illustrated in Figure 5 for the case of symmetric wall heating, β=1 . It is significant to observe the non-influential role of Br on the variation of Nusselt numbers from the above figure. For the case of symmetric wall heating β=1 , both the limiting Nusselt numbers become independent of Br , which shows similarity with the case of viscous heating effect in a vertical channel.20 However, in case of β=1 , the limiting Nusselt number on both the walls shows similarity in behavior with the cases having β≠1 as R*→1 . This is solely attributed to the movement of the inner cylindrical rod. Figure 5.
The influence of Br , on the Nuc for β=1 .

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, the effects of both the viscous dissipation and the degree of asymmetry parameter on the heat transfer characteristics within a Newtonian fluid flowing through an asymmetrically heated annulus have been investigated. Explicit and closed-form expressions of Nusselt number for a fully developed flow of a Newtonian fluid through an annulus have been devised. Different cases have been demonstrated, and interesting features that may play vital role on the heat transfer analysis in the limiting condition have been presented. The influential role of viscous dissipation is found to be of great importance in the heat transfer analysis when both the plates are kept at unequal constant temperatures; hence an emphasis on viscous dissipation has been given to include the effect of shear stress induced by the axial movement of the inner cylindrical rod in addition to the effect of viscous dissipation due to the internal fluid friction. A few assumptions have been made in the present analysis. Scope of future research is there to extend the domain of the analysis by reducing the number of assumptions. Following conclusions can be drawn from the investigation made in this study.
Limiting Nusselt numbers at both the walls are found to be independent of the Brinkman number in case of symmetric wall heating.
The temperature profile obtained in the conduction limit including the effect of viscous dissipation provides a boundary condition required for solving energy equation that includes the axial conduction in the fluid.
The limiting values of Nusselt number at both the walls of the annulus do not match as R*→1 for the cases of asymmetry in wall heating, i.e. β≠1 . This is because of the movement of the inner cylinder, which provides additional shear stress in the fluid that increases the viscous heating, resulting in an enhancement in the heat transfer at the inner wall of the annulus.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: a constant and is equal to −Br/(ln R*)2
limiting heat transfer coefficient at inner wall (W/m2-K)
limiting heat transfer coefficient at outer wall (W/m2-K)
Nusselt number in the conduction limit at the inner wall of the annulus
Nusselt number in the conduction limit at the outer wall of the annulus
velocity of the moving cylindrical rod (m/s)
dimensionless mean temperature in the conduction limit
